title: Jets aiming to end eight - year drought after crushing Phoenix loss | Newcastle Herald
body_text:
The Newcastle Jets wasted little time dwelling on a season-worst result at the hands of high-flying Wellington Phoenix.
Subscribe now for unlimited access.
or signup to continue reading
Less than 12 hours after the horror 5-1 loss in testing weather conditions at No.2 Sportsground on Sunday night, they were back at training analysing what went wrong.
Leading striker Melina Ayres reckons it could prove the jolt they needed with seven games remaining and finals still firmly within their grasp.
"We had a pretty big review after that and just sort of nipped everything in the bud Monday," Ayres told media on Thursday.
"We were back in training at 6am, so it was good to get that out of the way and realise the things that we needed to work on.
"We've trained pretty hard this week and we can only look forward now. That's our biggest loss this year and it's really just kicked everyone into gear.
"Hopefully it's one loss we had to have. But it highlighted things that we do need to be really switched on with, and hopefully we can bounce back this weekend."
The Jets produced a huge result south of the border on January 21, beating A-League Women heavyweights Melbourne City for the first time in the history of the competition.
They are targeting another big win in Victoria on Saturday night (7.30pm) against Ayres' former club Melbourne Victory in Shepparton.
It has been more than eight years since the Jets beat Victory on the road, a 3-1 triumph on December 29, 2017.
A win would not only boost the Jets' confidence, it could lift them back into the top six.
MORE SPORT:
Newcastle are ninth on 16 points, just one point below Victory (17) with a game in hand and only three points adrift of sixth-placed Central Coast (19).
Leaders City (23) are only four points ahead of the Mariners.
"Some people don't like to think about the ladder, but I know I want to play finals, so I'm looking at it and each game's so important from now on," Ayres said.
"It's there for the taking for sure."
To be a chance of success, the Jets need to be steelier in defence across the park.
Three of Phoenix's goals came from outside of the 18-yard box and from players who were not challenged.
After conceding five goals, four in the first 23 minutes, the Jets are now the second leakiest side in the league.
Up the other end, Ayres was Newcastle's lone scorer, taking her season tally to four when she pounced on a rebound.
Newcastle are taking plenty of chances - they have the fourth-highest statistic for shots attempted in the competition - but need to be clinical.
Victory were ruthless with their chances when they beat the Jets 3-1 in Newcastle on December 18, but they have not won a game since.
Seventeen-year-old goalkeeper Georgia Ritchie could retain her place in the Jets' starting side after making her A-League debut against Wellington in place of injured New Zealand international Anna Leat (shoulder).
Leat remains in doubt this weekend and the Newcastle Herald understands captain Cassidy Davis could also miss the trip south as she manages ongoing foot issues.
Meanwhile, attacking player Charlotte Lancaster has earned her first call-up to the New Zealand senior squad after scoring three goals in eight appearances for the Jets.
Lancaster and Jets forward Kelli Brown were named in the Football Ferns' squad for upcoming World Cup qualifying matches in the Solomon Islands.
